#LetsMeet Phillip Tan, recipient of the MSF Outstanding Lifetime Volunteer Award, who has served in the social service sector for 39 years. A champion for community giving, Phillip has helmed @comchestsg since 2013. He believes everyone, including the young, has the capacity to give back and help those in need. One of his many notable contributions was leading the Care and Share @ SG50 Movement which saw 240 social service agencies raise a total of $800 million.

“The most rewarding part about volunteering is the smiles of happiness from the faces of service users and their caregivers and knowing that the little you’ve done has made a difference to people’s lives.

My advice to new volunteers is to enjoy volunteerism, don’t treat it as a chore. Enjoy the companionship and the lifelong friendship with your fellow volunteers and beneficiaries. Don’t worry about the result, just focus on doing good.”

If you are looking for ways to make a difference, join us and our partners to nurture and build lives together. Visit msf.gov.sg/volunteer to learn more!

#MSFCareNetwork

Meet our scholar, Kirsten Ho, a Senior Early Childhood Officer at @beanstalksingapore (ECDA). She graduated with a Bachelors in Psychology from Yale-NUS College, and a Master in Child Development from University College London.

“When I was young, I frequently helped to babysit children. I didn’t just enjoy playing with the babies and toddlers – I loved taking care of them, teaching them, and watching them explore the world. It was the beginning of my interest in child development. 

I applied for MSF’s scholarships and pursued opportunities such as the exchange programme in the United States in my third year of university, and in London for my Master’s programme. These had broadened my understanding on child development and education beyond Singapore.

As a policy officer, I develop and review policies and programmes, where I conduct research and collaborate regularly with stakeholders. MSF is the place for you if you enjoy working with people and are passionate about making a difference.”

At MSF, we develop talent to its fullest potential and provide a meaningful career. Learn more at go.gov.sg/msf-scholarships.

#LetsMeet Betty Chen, a recipient of the MSF Outstanding Lifetime Volunteer Award. At 95, Mrs Chen is a pioneer in the social service sector. She is an advocate for women’s development in Singapore, having served as the president of the Chinese Women’s association for 26 years. She is also passionate about caring for elderly and managed the Henderson Senior Citizens’ Home for 32 years where she forged best practices in senior care. Over the decades, she has raised funds for countless social causes and charities.
 
Encouraging the next generation of volunteers, Mrs Chen said: “Volunteering should be undertaken with genuine interest, intent and commitment. If one is truly interested in a project, you will find out how to make your efforts work. All problems can be solved somehow, if you work at it with fellow interested persons who enjoy challenges. I’m also pleased that there are more young people starting associations to help others. It is wonderful to see.”

Join us and our partners to nurture and build lives together, visit msf.gov.sg/volunteer to find out more!

Family Service Centres (FSC) play a key role in building strong and stable families in Singapore today. They serve individuals and families who need support, to help them cope better with their challenges. However, not many may know that the FSC concept was one of the contributions of pioneer social worker, Thung Syn Neo. 

Starting out as a medical social worker before she became a social work lecturer, Syn Neo eventually took on the role of Director of the Development Division at the then-Ministry of Social Affairs. 

While at the ministry, she led a team of social welfare officers to develop a pilot project for a one-stop community-based centre providing services to support needy families. Partly funded by UNICEF (United Nations Children's Fund), this pilot project helped to bring social work efforts into the community and marked the start of the FSCs we are now familiar with. There are 48 FSCs located around the island today.

When Dr Kanwaljit Soin was 10 years old, she met a kind doctor in Indonesia who inspired her to become one herself. Years later, she became Singapore’s first female orthopaedic surgeon.

Beyond helping people in the medical field, Kanwaljit is also passionate about advocating for women’s rights. As the first woman in Singapore to become a Nominated Member of Parliament in 1992, she sparked discussions in Parliament on topics such as gender implications in government policies and even proposed the Family Violence Bill. Although it was not passed, key propositions of the bill were later incorporated in reviews of the Women’s Charter. One such proposition was the introduction of Personal Protection Orders for domestic abuse victims.

The former 1992 ‘Singapore’s Woman of the Year’ was also the founding chair of the Singapore chapter of the United Nations Development Fund for Women (UNIFEM), the founding president of Women’s Initiative for Ageing Successfully (WINGS), and a former president of the Singapore chapter of the International Women’s Forum. 

#CelebratingSGWomen

#LetsMeet a pioneer in Singapore’s charity food landscape, Mr Tony Tay, the founder of @willingheartssg – a soup kitchen that prepares and distributes around 11,000 meals daily to those in need. Willing Hearts has a simple philosophy – "Come See, Judge and Act".

“We started Willing Hearts in 2005 to make sure that those in need do not have to go hungry. Time is the most important thing that our volunteers can give. We put in the time not just to prepare meals for those in need, but also to engage them, understand their problems, and visit them regularly. Some volunteers arrive as early as 4.30am to help out at our kitchen before they head to work. Their energy keeps us going.”

Willing Hearts is part of the cross-sector Charity Food Workgroup that works on improving the coordination of charity food support. Willing Hearts relies mainly on volunteers to run their daily operations. Find out how you can help: https://willinghearts.org.sg/volunteer-opportunities/✨

#FoodHeroes #BetterGiving #SGCares

#LetsMeet Samantha Claire Bernard, a 23-year-old volunteer, who has been reaching out to rough sleepers in the community since 2019 with @cwshelps (Catholic Welfare Services) Night Missions Programme.

“My first Night Missions session took place around Ang Mo Kio central, a place I frequented with my friends. I never noticed the individuals lying on cardboards or hard concrete floors until that night as we walked along those familiar streets. I realised how ignorant I had been.

“It brings me so much joy to befriend the rough sleepers, who often have wise words and advice for me, and the conversations are some of the highlights of my week. It may seem like we are there to help them, but they are also helping us. I have come to realise how support and a listening ear can go a long way to help.”

To find out how you can support rough sleepers and the homeless in Singapore, visit go.gov.sg/PEERS-Network

She was one of the first three women elected to Parliament in 1984. As a sociologist, Dr Aline Wong was familiar with the inequalities women in Singapore faced, and she welcomed the opportunity to address these challenges as a Member of Parliament. 

In her 17-year career in politics, she played an active part in advocating for fairer conditions for women, such as more flexible work arrangements and improved childcare facilities. She launched a sexuality education framework for schools, supported improvements and raised standards for both early childhood education and special needs education. She also led the PAP’s Women’s Wing from its establishment in 1989 till 2001, when she retired from the political scene. 

Aline was later appointed as Singapore’s Representative for Women’s Rights to the ASEAN Commission on the Promotion and Protection of the Rights of Women and Children, and also became the first woman in Singapore’s educational history to be appointed as Chancellor of then-SIM University.

 #CelebratingSGWomen

Celebrating SG Women | She Who Left A Legacy

The late Daisy Vaithilingam was inspired to improve the lives of others by her parents, who both worked in the medical field. Her career as a medical social worker only began in 1952, when she joined Singapore General Hospital. At the time, Singapore was beset with problems after the Second World War, such as disease, poverty, and unemployment. Despite these, Daisy was determined to dedicate her life to help those in need. 

Throughout her career, Daisy pioneered many initiatives that significantly impacted Singapore and enabled progress on the social welfare front. These include establishing the first fostering scheme for children, where she assigned hospital attendants to care for children who had been abandoned. She was also passionate about helping children with intellectual disabilities, and would help their parents secure financial aid. In 1962, she led the creation of the current Movement for the Intellectually Disabled of Singapore (MINDS) to help children with disabilities integrate into society through education and training programmes.

Daisy also founded the Singapore Association of Social Workers, and started a community project alongside her team of social workers to house underprivileged women in a communal residence. Her passion for social work and compassion towards the less fortunate continues to live on in her enduring legacy. #CelebratingSGWomen

#LetsMeet Timothy Lai, Senior Manager of IT & Facilities, from @foodfromtheheartsg. Timothy and his team designed the FFTH community shops – minimarts that operate on a shop-for-free concept – for their beneficiaries.
 
“We created the community shops as an alternative to food pack distribution, to give our beneficiaries the dignity of choice.

Our two community shops in Mountbatten and Boon Lay are run by volunteers. Each beneficiary is given a card with a unique QR code, to redeem 12 food items monthly. From the data collected, we can better understand and cater to our beneficiaries’ needs. It also enables us to be more specific in seeking donations for more popular items like malt drinks or canned sardines.
 
Our surveys found that about 95% of our beneficiaries in Mountbatten prefer to go to our shop instead of receiving food packs. It gives them a reason to leave home to meet neighbours and have a chit chat. We also engage the community around the shops to donate food, which keeps the spirit of neighbours helping neighbours alive.”
 
FFTH is part of MSF’s Charity Food Workgroup that is working on better coordination of food support. Visit here to get involved! https://www.foodfromtheheart.sg/

In 1967, a time when sex was considered a taboo topic, Dr Nalla Tan championed for sex education to be taught in schools. She led a training course for teachers to educate their students and was also the head of a Singapore Medical Association committee that organised and launched the country’s first public health education programme. Her contribution to the public health education programme is just one of many ways her legacy continues to live on in Singapore. 

Beyond public health education, Dr Tan also advocated for women’s rights in the workplace and spoke about gender-associated prejudices that prevented women from rising up the corporate ladder. She proposed for a central organisation for women, such as a Women’s Affairs department, to be established. Her contributions helped elevate women’s status in employment, education and national development. Dr Tan received the Outstanding Women Award in 1975, and was presented with the Friend of Labour award from the National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) in 1984, for her dedication towards the labour movement and advocacy of female employment. #CelebratingSGWomen

The commemorative stamp was designed by Casey Ng, an artist with special needs from Singapore Fashion Runway, and Agnes Tan, a stamp designer. They used attributes and values that make the SG woman to recreate the Celebrating SG Women logo, which takes on the form of the national flower, Vanda Miss Joaquim.

“Women have empowering beauty and talents, and are also courageous, resilient, and inspiring. I’m glad to have played a part in designing the stamp and have my work showcased.” – Casey Ng, 17

“I hope all women in Singapore would be able to pursue their dreams and find their purpose regardless of which stage of life they are at. The stamp launch serves as a good chance to inspire and thank SG women.” – Agnes Tan, 27

“I’m a Community Nurse who serves patients living in the North-East. On a day-to-day basis, I make house visits to monitor a patient’s condition or to carry out certain procedures. I also communicate with the patient or their family members to provide updates on their progress, along with offering pointers to aid in their own patient care, or caregiving. 

As a nurse, I am thankful that the support system in my organisation has allowed me to continue doing what I love, alongside caring for my daughter as a first-time mum. With the many roles women take on in life – be it as daughters, wives, mothers, or caregivers – the support we receive from our families and employers plays an important part in helping us carry them out well, even as we pursue our passions at the same time.” – Catherine Heng

Celebrating SG Women | She Who Left A Legacy

A pioneering social worker, a dedicated teacher and mentor, and an activist for victims of domestic violence – these are just some of the ways the late Dr Myrna Braga-Blake is remembered today.

As a young woman, she developed an interest in social work while studying abroad, after being inspired by stories her cousin shared about her work in the sector. Upon her return to Singapore, Myrna pursued a Medical Social Worker diploma at the School of Social Work and worked as a medical social worker in local hospitals like KK Hospital. She later became an Assistant Lecturer at the University of Singapore’s Social Work Department in 1962. 

Although Myrna often travelled and lived overseas due to her husband’s work, her passion for social work remained strong. She pursued further social work education overseas before returning to Singapore to resume her career as a social work lecturer. 

Myrna was president of the Singapore Association of Social Workers (SASW) from 1982 to 1984. During her time with SASW, she helped ensure the quality and effectiveness of social work in Singapore, which is still in practice today. She also became a member of the first Management Committee of PAVE, Singapore’s pioneer family violence specialist centre, and was instrumental in developing services to help victims of domestic violence. 

In 1999, she received the Outstanding Social Worker award with Ms Ang Bee Lian, MSF’s current Director-General of Social Welfare, for her contributions to the community. Together, the ladies pooled their prize money to fund a foundation programme for fresh graduates entering the social work sector – ensuring they would be equipped with the necessary skills as they embarked on their social work journey. #CelebratingSGWomen

Celebrating SG Women | She Who Left A Legacy

Ann spent four years as a teacher at Methodist Girls’ School, and also taught social work classes on a part-time basis at the National University of Singapore, then known as University of Malaya in Singapore. She later became a training officer with the Social Welfare Department in 1955, where she was in charge of counselling and advice. She made house visits to low-income families in squatter areas and picked up Malay, Cantonese, Hokkien, and other dialects to better communicate and support her clients, many of whom were women that had been abandoned or abused by their husbands. 

In 1957, Ann started teaching full-time at the university, and eventually became head of the Department of Social Studies. She was determined to establish an Honours degree course, so social workers could earn more, like other Honours graduates, and also gain greater access to policy making with their valuable insights and knowledge from working on-the-ground. A four-year honours course was finally introduced in 1985 – just a year before her retirement. 

Thanks to Ann’s dedication and service, social workers in Singapore are able to achieve better career prospects, and be acknowledged as the professionals they are. #CelebratingSGWomen

#LetsMeet Madam Sarimah Binte Amat, a 54-year-old homemaker, who has been fostering children since 2012. Besides being a foster parent, Madam Sarimah has also taken the lead in bringing foster parents in her neighbourhood together.

"I remembered how excited and anxious I was when I met my first foster child the first time. The moment she reached out to me for comfort, I knew then that I was doing the right thing.

Fostering children has its own set of challenges and we have to adapt according to each child’s needs. It was all worth it when my foster children wrote me a 'Happy Mother’s Day' card, and I feel so much pride watching them grow and achieve various milestones. We celebrate their small successes to encourage them to strive towards their dreams.

I thought it was important for foster parents in the same neighbourhood to have a support group, so I organised some virtual get-togethers. Some of them are new foster parents, while others have fostering experience. Getting together gives us opportunities to interact, share resources and ‘lobangs’ with one another.”

“I’m a harbour pilot at PSA Marine. My main duty is to go onboard vessels and ensure their safe navigation in Singapore’s busy waterways. It is a heavy responsibility and I work closely with the vessel’s captain and bridge team. My interest in the maritime industry started when I was 15 years old and I’m glad I pursued my ambitions. What I like most about my job is how no two days are alike. I always get to meet new people and go on board different ships. People are often surprised to hear about my profession because the maritime industry is male-dominated. I often think about how lucky I am to do what I do, because I really love the job." – Farhana Binte MD Thair

We caught up with Farhana to learn more about how she got started, her experiences in a male-dominated industry, and her advice for others who want to pursue their ambitions.

Celebrating SG Women | She Who Left A Legacy

When Puan Noor Aishah became the First Lady of Singapore in December 1959, she was just 26-years-old and had little formal education. With no former First Lady to guide her, the wife of Singapore’s first locally-born Head of State Yusof Ishak navigated her role and responsibilities with charm, grace and determination. She managed a large household, organised receptions for visiting dignitaries, involved herself in various organisations and community activities, and even helped to carry out some official and ceremonial duties when her husband’s health started to decline. 

Puan Noor Aishah also introduced a uniquely Singaporean ambience into the Istana, teaching the chefs to whip up homely Asian fare like rendang and epok-epok, instead of English roast beef and pudding.

With her lifelong love for learning, Puan Noor Aishah took English lessons in her later years, which enabled her to make speeches at events. She became patron of organisations such as the Red Cross Society, the Children’s Society, the Association for the Blind, and the Association for the Deaf. As the patron for the Young Women’s Muslim Association (PPIS) and the Singapore Girl Guides Association, she helped  secure land for their headquarters. Her contribution to the Guiding movement in Singapore – both as patron and the Girl Guides’ first Asian president – enabled girls and women in uniform groups to learn useful skills and build a sense of independence through teamwork and leadership activities. 

In 1964, the Government awarded her with the Distinguished Service Medal for her dedication and active involvement in social welfare.

As we celebrate National Day this month, we remember the contributions made by Puan Noor Aishah in the early days of our independence, and her legacy as our nation’s first First Lady. 

#CelebratingSGWomen

Celebrating SG Women | She Who Left A Legacy

In the 1950s, women in Singapore were falling behind men in areas such as education and employment. Polygamy was accepted and many women lived in difficult circumstances. For the late Chan Choy Siong, a pioneering politician and campaigner for women’s rights, this was unacceptable. Despite being derided for her humble background as a hawker’s daughter, she was determined to achieve equality for women.

After being elected to the Legislative Assembly of Singapore, Choy Siong joined activists from the Singapore Council of Women in their call to better protect and speed up the emancipation of women. She campaigned for the drafting and passing of the Women’s Charter to put husband and wife on an equal footing before the law.

The Women’s Charter was enacted in 1961 to protect and advance the rights of women and girls in Singapore. Over the years, legislation has been reviewed to ensure the Charter stays relevant as society evolves. 

Today is the 60th anniversary of the Women’s Charter. In the Year of Celebrating SG Women, we celebrate the women, and men, who have championed initiatives for women’s development over the years. They have worked hard to set the foundation for our progress today.

“I went into family law quite early in my career, with a focus on women, as I found this area interesting. When I formed the Singapore Association of Women Lawyers in 1974, I wanted to help women in blue-collar jobs, who were often subjected to workplace harassment, to learn more about the law. I introduced free legal counselling for them by setting up counselling centres.
 
One of my most defining moments was securing a new headquarters for the Singapore Council of Women’s Organisations, which I was a founder member of. As we wanted a space of our own to host visitors from other women’s organisations, I remember going on an arduous hunt for locations and engaging in relentless negotiations, before we landed on 96 Waterloo Street – a place we could finally call home.
 
Over the years, being able to contribute to the developments of the legal profession relating to women and the family has been a memorable experience for me. It is important for our women to have a say in society, as it will continue to impact our lives. I set out to implement change for the next generation of women in Singapore, and today, I’m proud of far our women have progressed. Equality is not impossible.
 
I could only embark on this journey because I was able to stand on the shoulders of my predecessors. I really want to say ‘thank you’ to all my friends, family, and supporters, who have stood by me throughout.” – Anamah Tan, 81

#LetsMeet Elisa Lim, founder of @willandwell, an inclusive fashion label that designs apparels for those with disabilities or special needs.

"During the final year of my fashion diploma course, a doctor asked me to design clothes for his bedridden patients who faced challenges getting dressed. This was when I realised there was a need in this area that I could address with my skills.

To design these apparels, we first have to understand our clients’ needs through observation and conducting interviews with them. We then ideate and test the practicality of the designs before going into production. Once, there was an 6-year-old girl with a stump on one arm who needed alterations to her school apron, as it was difficult for her to tie it around her back. We helped her to get around this with our SwipeFit function, which allowed her to fasten the apron easily through Velcro tapes.

For the past 13 years, Sheila (not her real name) had been living with her maternal step grandmother as her mother was struggling with relationship, employment and housing issues.
 
When Sheila was found misbehaving both at home and in school, her maternal step grandmother gave her an ultimatum: live with her mother, or be sent to the Singapore Girls’ Home.
 
Sheila eventually returned to her mother’s care, but unfortunately had difficulty bonding with her family. She ran away from home, mixed with bad company, experimented with inhalants and engaged in underage sex.

Kelly (not her real name) was exposed to domestic violence from a young age, and she felt that she had never received love from her parents. When she turned 13, her mother passed away and she had to live alone with her abusive father, who even disallowed her to mourn for her deceased mother.
 
Traumatised, Kelly had difficulties managing her emotions and started to self-harm. One day, she overdosed on depressants and was admitted into a psychiatric hospital.
 
For her safety and well-being, Kelly was referred to MSF’s Child Protective Service (CPS) and has been living in a Voluntary Children’s Home since she was 14.
 
Now 16, Kelly faces self-esteem issues but uses the skills she learnt in therapy to cope with her feelings and thoughts. Kelly’s father, however, has not visited her in 2 years, and refuses to work with CPS on reunification with her.
 
For youths like Kelly, the amendments to the Children and Young Persons Act are helpful. The newly-introduced Enhanced Care and Protection Order can allow her to continue living safely with a designated caregiver until she is independent, giving her more time to recover.

.
An avid dancer, Jane was touched when she received a pair of sneakers from her foster parents, as it symbolised their support for one of her greatest passions.
.
Today, she cherishes every moment she has with her foster family, and hopes that more families will step forward to offer their homes to youths like herself.
.

On #WorldSocialWorkDay today, #LetsMeet Sakshi Dovedy, 26, a Child Protection Officer at MSF.
.
“I chose to be a Child Protection Officer because I've always wanted to work with vulnerable children and families. Common misperceptions others have about these families are that they are disempowered and victims of their circumstances. Nothing can be further from the truth. The families I work with have taught me the power of hope and resilience, and what it means to never give up. In getting to know them, I seek out their strengths to help them achieve their potential.
.
Social Work can get challenging but social workers never walk alone. The children and families are supported by people like myself and professionals in the community who journey alongside them. When tough days come, I look at the children to remind myself why I joined the Child Protective Service in the first place.”

#FACESOFMSFCARES - MORE COMPREHENSIVE, CONVENIENT AND COORDINATED SUPPORT FOR LOW-INCOME AND VULNERABLE FAMILIES
“Many of the families in the Jalan Kukoh community that we support have multi-faceted needs, ranging from financial to more complex family needs. And while there are resources within the community, it is not always easy for families to know where these services are, and how to get to them.
Community Link is an opportunity for us, as community partners, to work together more purposefully, and be more proactive in reaching out to residents. It is also a chance for us to create programmes that are more community-based, with residents and volunteers involved.
As for the residents, my hope is that Community Link will be a space that they can walk into with ease, to be linked up with the services they need, and be engaged in the different programmes available. By working together hand in hand with a common vision, we can uplift families.” – Annie Chia, 42, Principal Social Worker, Montfort Care – Kreta Ayer Family Services
This year, MSF will be working with community partners like Kreta Ayer Family Services to launch Community Link in four estates to better support families living in rental flats.

For Faith, the journey to accepting and loving herself was a challenging one. Being hearing impaired and having a condition that limits her vision made it hard for Faith to secure employment and be financially independent. As a result, she struggled to see her value and fell into depression. It was then that her sister decided to start @bloomback_ig a floral gifts e-commerce that provides marginalised women with training in floristry, to integrate them back into society.

Working in BloomBack empowered Faith with these essential work and life skills. She now conducts workshops, communicates with suppliers and customers and even sells BloomBack’s products. As BloomBack's lead fresh flower designer, Faith is now a confident individual who has grown to understand the importance of self-love.
Support BloomBacks mission of being the vehicle of empowerment for ladies like Faith!

#FACESOFMSFCARES – MORE CHILD CARE SUBSIDIES FOR NON-WORKING MOTHERS LOOKING FOR WORK OR CARING FOR THEIR YOUNGER CHILD
“My children are my everything. As a mother, I recognise that the early years are important in my children’s development, so I made the conscious decision to put a hold on my career to care full time for them. I hope to return to work when my younger child is older and I can put her in childcare.
I do what I can to give my children the best, but sometimes, this adds to our expenses. These everyday expenses can put pressure on my husband as the sole breadwinner of our family.
So it gives me a greater peace of mind that I qualify for more child care subsidy support from the Government, and for a longer period of time too! This eases my worry on subsidies for my older one in child care, and helps me focus on nurturing my younger one at home.” – Lee Siok Hong, 38, mother of two, with her baby daughter Mavis.
Siok Hong’s family is one of around 5,000 households who are expected to benefit from enhanced child care subsidy support from the Early Childhood Development Agency (ECDA) from 1 March this year.

#FACESOFMSFCARES - INCREASE IN COMCARE LONG-TERM ASSISTANCE AND SHORT-TO-MEDIUM TERM ASSISTANCE
“Everyone in my neighbourhood knows me. I go to the Senior Activity Centre almost every day to talk to my friends there and do my favourite colouring activity. I also take part in activities by Handicaps Welfare Association and Singapore Cancer Society. On Saturday mornings, I go to church. You can say I am quite busy!
I may have polio, but I still try to live life to the fullest. This week, I’m going to help Singapore Cancer Society with their fundraising event. I’m a bit nervous, but I’m looking forward to it.
With my condition, finances can be tight, but I get help from the Government for my medical and daily living expenses. This means less worry for my family. If I have problems, I can always talk to the staff from Fei Yue Senior Activity Centre, or Priya from the Social Service Office.
I am also close to my family. We are a big family - I have sisters, one brother, nieces and nephews. They are like my friends, because they always like to joke around and ‘disturb me’!
But seriously, I cannot imagine my life without my family. Especially my sister who stays with me, and makes sure I am okay. She looks strict, but I know deep down inside she cares.”
– Mdm Jaya Lidya d/o Samuel (left), 70, with her officer from MSF’s Social Service Office @ Hougang Priya Sreetharan (right). Mdm Jaya receives ComCare Long Term Assistance (LTA), Silver Support payouts and Pioneer Generation healthcare benefits alongside support from community partners such as befriending services.
From 1 July 2019, ComCare LTA beneficiaries like Mdm Jaya will receive an increase in cash assistance. ComCare LTA supports Singaporeans who cannot work due to old age, illness or disability, and have little or no income and family support. Many of them are elderly Singaporeans like Mdm Jaya.

#FACESOFMSFCARES “Music keeps me going. It reinvigorates me and reminds me of all the young people whose lives I have influenced, and those whom I have yet to mentor.

When I was young, I wasn’t very good at expressing my thoughts and feelings, and didn’t have many friends. My only outlet then was playing the guitar and that gave me a voice to express myself. My experiences have helped me empathise with others who have similar challenges. As an Assistant Lead of the Therapeutic Group Home at Boys Town, I’ve had the privilege of overseeing youths who have gone through acute or complex trauma. My main objective is to help these youths integrate into society, and have a second shot in life. Everyone deserves a chance, and I thought, if I have the ability to bring that chance to them, why not? My work at Boys’ Town has been rewarding, especially when we see our youths improving and progressing well. Results certainly do not come easy, so a little patience and a whole lot of passion go a long way! Whenever I encounter a case that is particularly trying, I remind myself why I signed up in the first place. I pause for a minute, play a few tunes and push on again.
I’m glad that we can also see what lies ahead for us as social service professionals. The Skills Framework for Social Service has helped shed light on progression paths that one can take in this sector. I can also clearly explain to my team the different job roles, tasks and relevant skills they need to equip themselves with, to plan for their career development.”– Muhammad Farhan Bin Kamsani, 29, Assistant Lead of the Therapeutic Group Home at Boys’ Town. Farhan supervises a team of officers in providing therapeutic care to youths aged 12- to 16-years-old who have experienced acute or complex trauma. The Skills Framework for Social Service helps professionals like Farhan to map out career progression pathways, and guides organisations in developing talent. MSF will also be setting up a new Social Service SkillsFuture Tripartite Taskforce, comprising sector professionals, academics and policymakers, to build on these efforts and drive skills development initiatives in the social service sector.

#FACESOFMSFCARES - EXTENSION OF POST-CARE SUPPORT “I was very rebellious when I was young. I didn’t like my parents as I found it hard to communicate with them. I spent more time with my friends, and got influenced by them. I always wanted to prove myself, but in the wrong way, like through fighting.

After everything happened, I realised it was not worth it. I got in and out of the Singapore Boys’ Home several times for remand and detention. My father kept visiting me when I was in remand until he almost lost his job. I remember when the Police came to arrest me, my mother pleaded to the Police not to handcuff me. The last time I went to the Singapore Boys’ Home, I had already given up on myself.

But my parents did not give up on me. I was touched and decided then that I must change and not make my parents sad.

I made good use of my time in the Home. I continued with my studies and picked up new skills, like specialty coffee making. I also did an internship with Bettr Barista. The teachers, Youth Guidance Officers, and my case worker were supportive, and always took the time to find out how I was doing.

I have since moved on with life and worked briefly before enlistment to National Service. I hope to earn more money in future and be filial to my parents.” - Jervin Tay, aged 19, former resident of Singapore Boys’ Home, with his family and case worker Lim Li Min (seated, right). Currently, youth discharged from MSF Youth Homes are provided with post-care support for up to two months upon completion of their Court Orders. MSF will extend post-care support from two months to a year in a pilot programme to better strengthen the transition and reintegration of youth into the community. This builds on MSF’s work to support at-risk youth with opportunities to achieve success. They may be first-time parents, but Mr Kevin Woo, a 45-year-old real estate agent and his wife, Mdm Siti Raziah, a 45-year-old healthcare coordinator, are no strangers to fostering. They started fostering in 2013, and are currently caring for 2 boys aged 4 and 7, and a girl aged 10. 
Mr Woo and Mdm Siti would love to have children of their own, but were unsuccessful, and hence considered fostering. “We saw fostering as a good start for us,” said Mr Woo. “We are able to do something to help the less fortunate and while contributing, we are also getting a taste of family life with children.

Based on their experience, their advice to those who are thinking of becoming foster parents is to learn as much as they can about fostering beforehand. “You are taking care of a child temporarily and you have to manage your expectations,” said Mdm Siti. 
On what fostering means to them, Mr Woo has this to say: “We are bringing them up while being very clear in our heads that we are doing this for them. We are doing this because we are able to provide the care that they need right now.” If you are keen to know more about the fostering scheme, visit www.msf.gov.sg/fostering.

#DidYouKnow that the volunteers who helped run Children’s Social Centres had backgrounds in nursing or first aid, and volunteer doctors would carry out medical checks to ensure the health and well-being of children? This proved useful because early detection helped the children get access to proper medical treatment.

Today, childcare centres need to adhere to regulatory requirements set by the Early Childhood Development Agency to ensure the safety, well-being and welfare of children. For example, daily temperature and health checks are conducted, and reporting systems are in place to ensure that children promptly receive any needed follow-up.

Neighbourhood Health Services Kids and ECDA organized the first ever child health and development screening this weekend. It provides free screening for children 0-6 living in Boon Lay rental flats. Families and children are also linked up with social services and the community. The programme is a good example of two areas that we have been actively working on : First, moving upstream with preschool programmes and family support, so that every child can have a good start in life regardless of family circumstances. Second, it illustrates the collective impact we can achieve when partners across various sectors come together to integrate our services to better serve the multi-faceted needs of underprivileged families. A job well done by @nhskids with support from @temasekfoundationcares , ECDA, community agencies, Boon Lay YEC, Thye Hua Kwan Moral Society (THK) FSC, South West CDC, My First Campus, One Youth volunteers, and the many medical, dentistry, nursing and social work students and professionals who volunteered their time and energy for this very meaningful programme. @msfcares @singaporecares #desmond.lee

The Ministry of Social and Family Development (MSF) is greatly saddened by the passing of former cabinet minister, Mr Othman Wok. 
As one of Singapore’s founding leaders, Mr Othman was the first Minister for Social Affairs. Over his 15 years of service, he worked to advance the quality of social welfare service from the basic functions of assistance and rehabilitation, to also focus on social progress for national development. 
Mr Othman’s visionary step of initiating the predecessor of the National Council of Social Service helped to create a more effective social service ecosystem. He also championed the training of social workers and volunteers to better equip them with skillsets needed. 
Mr Othman’s tireless efforts in shaping the social sector in Singapore set a solid foundation for all of us at MSF to build upon. He will be dearly missed.

The Ministry of Social and Family Development (MSF) is greatly saddened by the passing of former President of Singapore, Mr S R Nathan. Over the years, Mr Nathan had guided us on how to do good, and how to do it well. His advice was simple – everything we do should serve the needs of the disadvantaged and improve the quality of their lives.  Mr Nathan’s care and concern for workers and clients in the social service sector had touched many lives and he will be fondly remembered. 
But beyond the time and effort spent by Mr Nathan in doing his part for charity, he has left us with a lasting legacy and system of empathy, care and concern for Singaporeans in need. His visionary step of establishing the President’s Challenge in the year 2000 had resulted in S$160 million raised for supported charities. Since then, more than 20,000 Singaporeans from all walks of life have also volunteered their time and skills for the President's Challenge Volunteer Drive. 
Mr Nathan’s life embodies the spirit of MSF’s mission: Resilience, strength and care. Our memories of Mr Nathan shall live on in these values that guide MSF and our officers’ work in helping Singaporeans. He will be dearly missed.

In 1967, the first batch of NUS Social Work students graduated with a degree in social work. At that time, social service as a field of study was dismissed as “merely vocational” and did not have any academic standing.
.
After years of hard work by two pioneers in the local social work education scene – Miss Jean Robertson and Mrs Ann Wee – the department of social work soon became one of international repute. Social work undergraduates are exposed to a wide range of fieldwork placements to gain necessary field-learning experience; with increasing demands for skills in areas like social work research and programme evaluation, management, staff development and social entrepreneurship.
.
Evolving overtime to keep up with changing times and social scenes, the social work education landscape has grown to include postgraduate studies.

Today, NUS offers a Masters of Social Work, Masters of Social Sciences (Social Work by Research) and a Doctorate of Philosophy in Social Sciences (Social Work by Research).
.
The picture above features three distinguished alumni from the NUS Department of Social Work – Ms Koh Wah Khoon, Dr S Vasoo and Mr Udhia Kumar – who were the inaugural recipients of the Ann Wee NUS Social Work Alumni Award; that recognises alumni who have made major contributions to the social work education and practice.

Did you know that lonely people are more likely to engage in unhealthy behaviours? This is especially worrying as Singapore is facing rapid ageing population and the number of seniors aged 65 and above, who live alone, has tripled since 2000. Studies have found that lonely seniors are more likely to report risky health behaviours such as poor diet, lack of physical activity, and smoking. Conversely, social support can help encourage seniors to eat well, exercise, and live healthy lifestyles. Check out the various wellness programs available for seniors at www.successful-ageing.sg 😊 
Nonetheless, the most effective prevention is to maintain connections with your senior loved ones. After all, making an elderly feel loved and connected to the rest of the family is part of exercising filial piety.

In 1963, a new full-fledged ministry dealing with social affairs was established. The Ministry of Social Affairs – led by then Minister Othman Wok – took over a large slice of responsibilities that were previously held by the then Ministry of Labour, including overseeing the Social Welfare Department. The responsibilities falling under the new Ministry mainly involved the Country’s social welfare issues. Other facets that came under its jurisdiction include the Legal Aid Bureau, Registry of Muslim Marriages, Syariah Court, Registry of Marriages, Hindu Advisory Board and Sikh Advisory Board. 
Today, MSF oversees the country’s social issues – ranging from care for the needy and the disabled, to support for children and families – to build a more caring and resilient society.  #ThrowbackThursday #msfcares

In 1958, the Voluntary Welfare Organisations (VWOs) in Singapore were brought together under the Singapore Council of Social Service (SCSS). With Dato Lee Kong Chian as the President of its founding executive committee, the SCSS – which coordinated and promoted the roles and contributions of VWOs – provided remedial services, which then freed time for the government to focus on providing essential services such as housing and healthcare for the masses. 
In 1992, the SCSS was renamed the National Council of Social Service (NCSS). Today, the NCSS acts as a Statutory Board under MSF, acting as the national coordinating body for VWOs in Singapore.
